summary: David Patterson gratefully acknowledges the Gadigal people of the Eora Nation as the traditional owners of the land now called Sydney, Australia, where he was born. He believes we can learn much from Aboriginal Australians and other indigenous peoples about a sustainable balance between people and planet. Patterson has over 25 years' experience in global health, law and development with the UN system, intergovernmental organizations and NGOs including the International Development Law Organization (IDLO), UNAIDS, UNDP, WHO, ILO, and the (former) International HIV/AIDS Alliance. His academic qualifications include masters’ degrees in law (McGill), and public policy & management (London - SOAS), as well as post-graduate studies in community health (Montreal), adult education, and program evaluation (IPDET - World Bank & Carleton U). In 1993 Patterson co-founded the Canadian HIV/AIDS Legal Network and later, as Director of International Programs, created the Network's HIV and law programs in the Caribbean and in East Africa. From 2009-2023 he initiated and advised IDLO's Health Law Program. Patterson has mobilized over US $12 million to strengthen and expand HIV-related legal services and rights in more than 25 low and middle-income countries and to build legal capacity to address non-communicable diseases. Patterson also led IDLO’s collaboration with WHO on global health law and produced the 2017 report ‘Advancing the Right to Health: the vital role of law’ (written by Prof. Roger Magnusson and co-published with WHO, the O’Neill Institute and the University of Sydney.) Patterson is a member of the Groningen Centre for Health Law,  a PhD Candidate in the Faculty of Law at the University of Groningen, and a founding member of the Law and Public Health Section of the European Public Health Association (EUPHA). His current research is on the role of human rights law in the global response to climate change, through a public health lens.

profile_positions.description: My role within the IDLO Department of Global Initiatives 2014-2016 was to develop and maintain the institutional health law strategy to position IDLO as a leader, innovator, and pioneer in health, law and development, as well as in thought leadership, knowledge generation and policy. Over this period I expanded IDLO’s health law program to include East Africa region through grants from the World Bank, the DREAMS Innovation Fund and PEPFAR/UNAIDS. I supported program implementation, including through field visits, including to Middle East and North Africa region (Egypt, Jordan, Lebanon) and to East Africa (Uganda). In June 2015 I led a multi-agency scoping mission to Uganda to assess opportunities for addressing the issue of falsified medicines. During this period I built relationships with leading health agencies which led to  MOUs between IDLO and WHO, UNAIDS, and the Caribbean Public Health Agency (CARPHA).  In addition, I contributed to thought leadership and policy dialogue in health, law and development through research, publications, conferences and other external meetings, in collaboration with academic and other partners. This included building  links with academic institutions in the Netherlands, including the University of Groningen, with which IDLO cohosted a seminar on NCDs and law in 2015 in our branch office in The Hague. In February 2016 I organized a thematic discussion on NCDs and law at the UN Interagency Task Force on NCDs, at UN Headquarters in New York. I also strengthened IDLO’s networks, alliances, and partnerships with relevant governments, multilateral organizations, NGOs and civil society organizations, universities, and think-tanks. In 2015 I was appointed as a Commissioner to the Lancet Commission on Obesity.
profile_positions.title: Senior Legal Expert, Health

profile_positions.description: Over this period I led the articulation, design and implementation of IDLO programs and projects in the social development stream. This included the health law program, with a focus on HIV, and research and publications on the right to food, in close collaboration with the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO). The role included the management of staff performance and development through regular performance feedback. Most important was the motivation, coaching, and supporting of staff, while encouraging initiative and innovation.
profile_positions.title: Head, Social Development Programs Unit

profile_positions.description: Over the period 2009-2011 I conceived, development and implemented the IDLO HIV and Health Law Program. I raised over $3.5m in funds for the program from bilateral, foundation and UN sources; published technical guidance in multiple languages; built IDLO’s reputation on HIV and law in Asia/Pacific, Middle East / North Africa, and West and Central Africa; and managed a dynamic team of five staff, plus an active intern program. I also broadened the program focus to include legal aspects of public health and non-communicable diseases; hosted two international consultations on public health law; and developed close working relationships with WHO and academic partners. During this period I managed the research and publication, with UNAIDS and UNDP, of the 'Toolkit: Scaling Up HIV-related Legal Services.' The Toolkit is now available in all 6 UN languages and has been disseminated widely.
